assessmentItem.title: Determine the exponential decay function in context

itemBody.p: The current in the branch of an electric circuit changes with time according to the formula

where
I 0
is the initial current and I is the current after t seconds.
It takes seconds for the current to drop to mA.
Enter your answers to 2 decimal places.

li.p: What is the current when t = fT2 seconds?

td.feedbackInline: You have not rounded your first answer correctly.

li.p: At what time is the current % of the original value?

td.feedbackInline: You have not rounded your second answer correctly.

feedbackBlock.p: You have had three attempts at answering this question, so here is the solution:

When t = fT , I = fI1 and
I 0
= iI0 , so

So the equation is
I = iI0

- fK4 t

When t = fT ,

fCurrent2 mA to 2 d.p.
\begin{eqnarray} I&=& \qv{iI0}e^{-\qv{fK4}\times\qv{fT}} &=&\qv{fCurrent2}\mbox{ mA to 2 d.p.} \end

To find the time when I = iPercent % of mA,
fPcAsDec × iI0
=
iI0
e
- fK4 t
fPcAsDec
=
e
- fK4 t
t

ln
fPcAsDec
- fK4
t

fTime2 seconds to 2 d.p.
\begin{eqnarray} \qv{fPcAsDec}\times\qv{iI0}&=& \qv{iI0}e^{-\qv{fK4}t} \qv{fPcAsDec}&=& e^{-\qv{fK4}t} \ln{\qv{fPcAsDec}}&=& -\qv{fK4}t t&=&\frac{\ln{\qv{fPcAsDec}}}{-\qv{fK4}} &=&\qv{fTime2}\mbox{ seconds to 2 d.p.} \end

feedbackBlock.p: Use the information provided to find k first, then substitute in the resulting equation to find the required values.
Since you have viewed the solution, your score for this question will be 0.
